prefix: Approach the following question the way someone in high school would.
problem_prompt: Approach the following question the way someone in high school would. Given that $13^{-1} \equiv 29 \pmod{47}$, find $34^{-1} \pmod{47}$, as a residue modulo 47.  (Give a number between 0 and 46, inclusive.)
gpt_response: To find $34^{-1} \pmod{47}$, first notice that $34 \equiv -13 \pmod{47}$. Then, we can rewrite $34^{-1} = (-13)^{-1}$. Since we are given that $13^{-1} \equiv 29 \pmod{47}$, it follows that $(-13)^{-1} \equiv -29 \equiv 18 \pmod{47}$. Therefore, $34^{-1} \equiv \boxed{18} \pmod{47}$.
solution_prompt: Yes or no, is the final solution obtained in the following equal to 18?: To find $34^{-1} \pmod{47}$, first notice that $34 \equiv -13 \pmod{47}$. Then, we can rewrite $34^{-1} = (-13)^{-1}$. Since we are given that $13^{-1} \equiv 29 \pmod{47}$, it follows that $(-13)^{-1} \equiv -29 \equiv 18 \pmod{47}$. Therefore, $34^{-1} \equiv \boxed{18} \pmod{47}$.
